task.title: Load Balancer Details - General
task.shortdesc: This tab allows you to view details about the load balancer and edit or add listeners, if necessary.

task.title: Load balancer
task.shortdesc: This section shows the name, the creation time and the security group associated with the load balancer. The only value you may change is the amount of time a connection to an instance can be idle before timing out. To change the idle timeout, type a new value in the Idle timeout (secs) control or use the up and down arrows to adjust the values incrementally.

task.title: Listeners
task.shortdesc: This section shows what listeners are currently assigned to the load balancer, but you may add more or edit one by deleting it and adding a new listener. A listener is the definition of protocols (client-side and instance-side) and ports that the load balancer uses to monitor and route incoming traffic to the load balancer's registered instances. A default listener is pre-defined with an HTTP protocol port 80 on the client and the instance side. You may delete a listener but you must define at least one listener to properly configure a load balancer.

step.cmd: To delete a listener, click the Remove listener icon (a minus sign in a circle) next to the one you want to remove.
To add a listener, scroll past the table (if a listener is already defined) and select an option from the Protocol drop-down list box for the CLIENT SIDE.
step.stepresult: The client-side port may be populated with a common default port for a chosen protocol but you can change the port, if neccessary.

step.cmd: If not already populated, or you want to change the client-side port, enter the port number in the Port text box.
step.info: Ports assigned for the client-side must be either 25, 80, 443, 465, 587 or from 1024 to 65535 and may not already be in use.

step.cmd: On the INSTANCE SIDE, select the protocol from the Protocol drop-down list box.
If not already auto-populated, enter the number of the instance-side port into the Port text box.

task.title: Security Policy
task.shortdesc: The ability to apply a security policy is only available if HTTPS or SSL is specified as the protocol.

step.cmd: The latest existing security policy is displayed by default next to Policy in the Security area but you may change it by clicking Change.
step.stepresult: The Select security policy window opens.

step.cmd: Select from the available security options:

choices.choice: Choose a predefined security policy and select a policy from the Policy name drop-down list box.

step.info: For more information on pre-defined security policies, go to AWS Predefined SSL Security Policies for Elastic Load Balancing OR

choices.choice: Create a custom security policy. Choosing this option opens the SSL PROTOCOLS and the SSL CIPHERS drop-down list box with values pre-populated.

substep.cmd: To delete any of the pre-populated values, click the x next to the value(s) you do not want.
To add or select another protocol, click in the SSL PROTOCOLS field and select one from the drop-down list box.
To add or select another encryption algorithm, click in the SSL CIPHERS field and select one from the drop-down list box.

info.note: You must specify at least one protocol and one encryption algorithm.

substep.cmd: In the SSL OPTIONS, click to select Server order preference if you want it for SSL negotiation.
Click the Use This Policy button to select the defined security policy.
substep.stepresult: The Select security policy window closes and the specified policy is displayed next to the Policy field.

task.title: Certificate
task.shortdesc: The ability to apply a security certificate is only available if HTTPS or SSL is specified as the protocol.

step.note: Skip this step if you want to continue using a certificate that is already installed on your load balancer.
step.cmd: To select a certificate, if available, click Select next to Certificates.
If a certificate is already assigned and you want to change it, click Change instead.
step.stepresult: Choosing this option opens the Select certificate(s) window. Tabs display for SSL and Backend only if the instance side uses HTTPS or SSL protocol.

step.cmd: Select from the available options for assigning a certificate to your load balancer:

choices.choice: Choose an existing SSL certificate from the Certificate Name drop down list, if available. If one is not available, upload a new certificate.
Upload a new SSL certificate. Choosing this option opens a form to upload a new certificate:

substep.cmd: Type the name of the new certificate in the Certificate name text field.
Paste the contents of your public key certificate file in the Public key certificate text field. Refer to the bubble help (?) for additional details.
Paste the contents of your private key certificate file in the Private key text field. Refer to the bubble help (?) for additional details.
Enter the contents of your certificate chain file in the Certificate chain text field.
To specify certificates for the backend, click the Back end tab. Otherwise, click the Use This Certificate button.
substep.stepresult: Choosing to specify the backend certificate(s) opens another form that may already be populated with pre-loaded certificates. Backend certificates are used to ensure added security measures between your load balancers and its communication with your server. Backend certificates are optional, but you may add multiple certificates on this form.

substep.cmd: To delete any of the pre-populated certificates, click the x next to the cetificate(s) you do not want.
To add or select another certificate, click Add a certificate or Add another certificate, respectively.
Type the name of the new certificate in the Certificate name text field.
Paste the contents of your certificate file in the Body (pem encoded) text field.
Click the Add Certificate button to add it.
Click the Use These Certificates button to apply the certificates to your load balancer.
substep.stepresult: The Select certificate(s) window closes and the specified certificate(s) is displayed next to the Certificates field.

substep.cmd: After listeners have been declared, click the Add Listener button to continue.
To add more listeners, repeat the above steps.

task.title: Access logs
task.shortdesc: This section displays the logs defined in the Create Load Balancer Wizard.

step.cmd: Click View latest log to open a separate window that contains the logs associated with your load balancer.
Click View my bucket to open an S3 bucket to view its contents.

task.title: Network & security
task.shortdesc: This section is only visible for load balancers in a VPC environment. The VPC network name and ID associated with the load balancer is not editable you may edit the security groups, if necessary.

step.cmd: To delete any of the security groups, click the x next to the one(s) you do not want.
To add a security group, type the first letters of the secuirty group name and choose the security group you want to add.
Click Save Changes to save your changes or Cancel to abandon your changes.
step.stepresult: The message, Successfully updated load balancer [name] indicates changes saved successfully.
